case_vignette: An 11-year-old girl is brought to her primary care physician by her mother with complaints of constant lower abdominal pain and foul-smelling urine for the past 2 days. The patient has had several previous episodes of simple urinary tract infections in the past. Her vitals signs show mild tachycardia without fever. Physical examination reveals suprapubic tenderness without costovertebral angle tenderness on percussion. Urinalysis reveals positive leukocyte esterase and nitrite. Further questioning reveals that the patient does not use the school toilets and holds her urine all day until she gets home. When pressed further, she gets teary-eyed and starts to cry and complains that other girls will make fun of her if she uses the bathroom and will spread rumors to the teachers and her friends. She reports that though this has never happened in the past it concerns her a great deal.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have constant lower abdominal pain and my urine smells bad.
Great, thank you for sharing that information. Can you tell me, are you a male or female? And approximately how old are you?
I'm an 11-year-old girl.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you some more questions to help narrow down the possible causes of your lower abdominal pain and bad-smelling urine.

Have you noticed any other symptoms such as fever, nausea, vomiting, or vaginal bleeding? And have you had any recent changes in your diet or sexual activity?
No, I don't have a fever, and I haven't had any nausea, vomiting, or vaginal bleeding.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you some more questions to help determine the cause of your bad-smelling urine and lower abdominal pain.

Have you noticed any changes in your urination habits, such as increased frequency or urgency? And have you had any recent travel or sexual exposure that could be related to your symptoms?
I haven't traveled or had any sexual exposure, but I don't use the school toilets and hold my urine all day until I get home.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and the fact that you hold your urine for long periods of time, it's possible that you may have a urinary tract infection (UTI). UTIs can cause bad-smelling urine, lower abdominal pain, and discomfort during urination.

I would recommend that you see a doctor as soon as possible for a proper evaluation and diagnosis. In the meantime, you can try drinking plenty of water to help flush out your system and alleviate your symptoms.

Final diagnosis: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having constant lower belly pain and my urine smells bad for the past 2 days.

Great, thank you for sharing that information! Can you tell me, have you noticed any changes in your urination frequency or volume? And have you experienced any other symptoms such as fever, chills, or nausea?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in how often or how much I pee, and I don't have a fever, chills, or nausea.

Okay, that's helpful to know. Have you ever experienced similar symptoms in the past, or is this a new development? And do you have any known underlying medical conditions, such as a urinary tract infection or kidney disease?
Yes, I've had several previous episodes of simple urinary tract infections before.

Great, that helps to narrow it down. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you a few more questions to confirm the diagnosis.

Can you tell me, have you noticed any blood in your urine or cloudy urine? And have you had any recent changes in your sexual activity or use of any new medications?
No, I haven't seen any blood in my urine or noticed it looking cloudy, and I haven't had any changes in sexual activity or started any new medications.

Okay, that's good to know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to perform a urinalysis to confirm the presence of a urinary tract infection. Can you please provide a urine sample for the test?

Also, have you noticed any discomfort or pain in your lower abdomen or back?
I can provide a urine sample, and yes, I do have discomfort in my lower belly, but my back doesn't hurt.

Great, thank you for letting me know. The urinalysis will help us determine if there is an infection in your urinary tract, and the discomfort in your lower abdomen could be related to the infection or another condition.

Can you please tell me, have you noticed any burning sensation while urinating or any difficulty starting to urinate? And have you had any recent travel or sexual exposure that could have caused this infection?
No, there's no burning when I pee or difficulty starting to pee, and I haven't traveled recently or had any sexual exposure.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would like to perform a urine culture to confirm the presence of a urinary tract infection. This will involve collecting a sample of your urine and sending it to the laboratory for testing.

Can you please tell me, have you ever had a urinary tract infection before? And have you noticed any other symptoms such as frequent urination, painful urination, or abdominal pain?
Yes, I've had urinary tract infections before, and I have this constant pain in my lower belly, but I'm not peeing more often or feeling pain when I do pee.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, it's possible that you have a kidney infection. I would like to perform a blood test to check your kidney function and rule out any other underlying conditions.

Can you please tell me, have you noticed any changes in your urine flow, such as a decrease in the amount of urine you produce or a change in the color of your urine? And have you had any recent changes in your diet or medications?
There haven't been any changes in how much I pee or the color of it, and I haven't changed what I eat or any medicines I take.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would like to prescribe you a course of antibiotics to treat the possible kidney infection. I would also like to schedule a follow-up appointment with you in a few days to check on your progress and make sure the infection is clearing up.

Can you please tell me, do you have any allergies or sensitivities to any medications? And do you have any other medical conditions that I should be aware of?
No, I don't have any allergies to medicines and I don't have any other medical conditions.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Here are the instructions for the antibiotics I would like to prescribe:

* Take 1 tablet of XYZ antibiotic once daily for the next 7 days
* Take with food to reduce stomach upset
* Complete the full course of antibiotics, even if you start to feel better, to ensure the infection is fully cleared
* If you experience any severe side effects or your symptoms worsen, seek medical attention immediately

Can you please confirm that you understand the instructions and are able to take the medication as directed?

Also, please let me know if you have any questions or concerns about the medication or your symptoms.
Yes, I understand how to take the antibiotics and I'll be sure to finish all of them and take them with food. I don't have any questions right now.

Great, thank you for confirming. I'm glad you understand the instructions and are committed to completing the full course of antibiotics. Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns in the future.

In the meantime, I would like to schedule a follow-up appointment with you in 3-4 days to check on your progress and make sure the infection is clearing up. Can you please let me know a convenient time for you to come in?

Also, please be sure to drink plenty of water and stay hydrated while taking the antibiotics, as this will help to flush the infection out of your system more effectively.

Thank you for your cooperation and I look forward to seeing you at your follow-up appointment.
Thank you, I will make sure to drink lots of water. We can come back for the follow-up in a few days; my mom will know the best time for us.

You're welcome! I'm glad to hear that you're taking good care of yourself and your mom. Please make sure to keep drinking plenty of water and to come back for your follow-up appointment so that we can check on your progress and make sure the infection is fully cleared up.

If you have any questions or concerns in the meantime, don't hesitate to reach out to me or your mom. We're here to help.

Take care and feel better soon!

Excellent, thank you for letting me know! Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask you a few more questions to help determine the possible cause of your lower abdominal pain and bad-smelling urine.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your history of recurrent urinary tract infections, it's possible that you may have a condition called vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). VUR is a condition where the flow of urine from the kidneys back to the bladder is abnormal, which can lead to recurrent infections.

I would recommend that you see a pediatric urologist for further evaluation and diagnosis. They will perform a series of tests to confirm the diagnosis of VUR and determine the best course of treatment.

In the meantime, it's important to drink plenty of water to help flush out your system and prevent future infections. You can also try taking a warm bath or using a heating pad on your lower abdomen to help alleviate any discomfort or pain.
